The Injured and Amputee Veterans Bill of Rights described in this subsection is a statement that injured and amputee veterans should have, at a minimum, the following rights:

header.#text: Injured and Amputee Veterans Bill of Rights

text.#text: The right to access the highest quality prosthetic and orthotic care, including the right to the most appropriate technology and best qualified practitioners.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: health care system, including comparable benefits relating to prosthetic and orthotic services.

text.#text: The right to continuity of care in the transition from the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , a private practitioner who has entered into a contract with the
to provide prosthetic and orthotic services, or a private practitioner with specialized expertise.

text.#text: The right to select the practitioner that best meets their orthotic and prosthetic needs, whether or not that practitioner is an employee of the
The right to consistent and portable health care, including the right to obtain comparable services and technology at any medical facility of the
The right to timely and efficient prosthetic and orthotic care, including a speedy authorization process with expedited authorization available for veterans visiting from another area of the country.
The right to play a meaningful role in rehabilitation decisions, including the right to receive a second opinion regarding prosthetic and orthotic treatment options.
The right to receive appropriate treatment, including the right to receive both a primary prosthesis or orthosis and a functional spare.
The right to be treated with respect and dignity and have an optimal quality of life both during and after rehabilitation.
The right to transition and readjust to civilian life in an honorable manner, including by having ample access to vocational rehabilitation, employment programs, and housing assistance.
